narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: General themes noted in revolutionary France regarding broad population-level movement.

Very few. The course was disorganized and chaotic. There was no apparent structure. Lectures were hard to follow and some readings difficult to obtain, while others were ridiculously overpriced for their quality or academic value.
I learned a lot about Revolutionary France and how to teach myself the history because I was so confused about what was presented in class.
Themes of Citizenship, Class Conflict, and State Terror

I learned about the main themes of the various revolutions in France from 1789-1871, and about the characteristics of the different governments that ruled France in the same time period. The various assignments throughout are also good exercises in thinking historically.

This course covers French history from the Revolution of 1789 through the Paris Commune of 1871. The course discusses the social, political, and economic factors that inspired the many revolts during this period. You also get practice developing and writing a historical research paper.

Working knowledge of French history between 1789-1871, with a primary focus on revolutionary and post-revolutionary reactions
Historical understandings of the development of French culture, society, and people
Insights on the influence of the time period on 20th and 21st century French history

I gained an understanding of the social and political themes that guided the course of French history in the 19th century, and practiced the modes of thinking and evaluation that historians use to study a certain event or time period.

I learned how to write a history paper and I learned a lot about the overall themes of the French Revolutions. I learned how to connect them and see the bigger picture. I also learned a lot about seeing history through the eyes of the worker.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Everything is harder in light of the pandemic! Professor Merriman did a wonderful job maintaining vibrant and colorful lecturing through zoom, especially when he could not see any of his students. He was very personable even through camera, and given the circumstances, this course was certainly the best it could have been in terms of relaying information. The only weakness is there could have been more assignments throughout the semester or something to encourage information retainment and not have the entirety of the grade come down to a final exam and paper only.

I was excited about this class because I'm much more familiar with British history and was eager to learn. Unfortunately, lectures were chaotic and nearly impossible to follow. The professor struggled with technology, he provided only random lists of terms, and there was no clear path for his narrative. He needs to retire. Readings were not well chosen and frankly his own textbook is overpriced. The only strength was that our TA worked hard to pull valuable information together for section.

Strength- interesting subject, Merriman is very knowledgable, not a lot of work or reading

Weakness- class is super disorganized, impossible to follow, limited feedback.

Strenghts: Merriman has a lot of knowledge about France and tis great to hear his anecdotes. He's super nice and a great guy. The TA staff was great, everyone was super understanding during the pandemic. 
Weaknesses: The course was a little unorganized during lectures.

Strengths: Merriman is incredibly knowledgeable and a great person, first of all. Second, the course is pretty easy to follow insofar as the themes are consistent through the time period we studied (e.g., class, religion, gender, region), and it's just a matter of thinking of how they change and influence French society and politics over time. Weaknesses: Probably just that sometimes the information from lecture wasn't too related to the assignments in the class.

Professor Merriman is phenomenal! His passion for and knowledge of the subject is inspiring. Sometimes it was difficult to follow the lectures because he doesn't use many slides, but I was always engaged even without the visual aids.

Strengths: 
broad, sizable, manageable list of primary and secondary sources
personal insights on Parisian culture and current political and social developments
structured syllabus with clear expectations
responsive to student input on courseload, content, and teaching style

Weaknesses: 
moves quickly with little time to discuss personal interests 
lectures can be meandering and sometimes irrelevant to course readings

Professor Merriman shares a wealth of stories and anecdotes that add color and detail to the lecture material and I enjoyed hearing them. I also appreciated the quick lecture notes he would send before each class with the key terms although they could still be more organized.

Merrimans lectures are interesting and he is very passionate about the subject. He gets into slightly off topic rants quite a bit which can be a strength or weakness depending on which way you look at it.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Lectures were poorly executed and disorganized. I don't know that it would have been any better in person. I can imagine Professor Blight or especially Professor Kennedy pulling off remarkable lectures even over Zoom because they are already strong teachers. I don't think this professor has that charisma or the ability to organize his thoughts into cohesive sets.
Improved- virtual lectures- more slides and more organized
1) I appreciated that the lectures were recorded, and 2) Having a live section was helpful for engaging the material outside of lecture.
The breakout rooms in section helped facilitate friendship and camaraderie among the students of the class.

Asynchronous access to the recorded lectures helped tremendously 
the tech aid was helpful

The slideshows in lecture were helpful to visualize the material especially the geography of France that I wasn't too familiar with. Although I attended lecture regularly, I did find it useful to rewatch certain recorded lectures to review the material.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would recommend it because of Professor Merriman! Very cool person to listen to, a very vibrant storyteller.

No. It makes no sense to backload course assignments so that both a final research paper and a final exam are required. Weekly discussion question requirements on top of section are a waste of time. And, the class is poorly organized and poorly taught.

Eh- if you are self-motivated and can study the history on your own, then yes. Do not expect to have a good grasp of the material by going to lecture. That being said, Merriman is funny and an interesting lecturer, he just goes off on tangents that aren't part of the course.

If you want to learn about France from 1789-1871, this is obviously the course to do it.  Merriman is also a great lecturer, and his knowledge of the period is unparalleled.  You'll talk a lot about social history and class conflict, so don't be surprised when you skim over Napoleon and the countless wars of this period.

Yes, I'd recommend it to someone who's interested in French history and/or politics (this is a really turbulent and interesting period in French history), or someone who's just looking for a cool history course to take (I'm a history major but the last time I studied European history was in high school). The course content progresses in a way that's easy to understand, it's interesting content, and Merriman is a nice person and knows what he's talking about.

Absolutely! This course is great for students who study history as well as those who have not taken a single course in the discipline. Professor Merriman is wonderful, so definitely try to take a class with him if you can.

Would highly recommend this course for any student interested in learning the basics of French history, especially in its most influential period relevant for today 
It provides a working general understanding of French history and the origins of current political and social state for students of many backgrounds, although a deep interest in French history and language is helpful
Yes, if you are interested in learning more about French or European history and how the country developed its political and social identity in this time period.
Definitely. Great way of learning this history with an incredibly interesting professor.
